div1.p: In the District Court of the United States, for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the matter of the Petition of Albert H. Young and Kamasaburo Sugiura, alias B.K. Sugiura, aliens, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus | #2628 Petitioners' reply brief
Argument

We shall take but little issue with counsel for the Government, upon the "RULE" and the "REASONS FOR THE RULE", bu which the Court is limited in this sort of proceeding, to the one question of whether or not the petitioners had a fair and legal hearing; and if so, whether there is, in the record, any evidence to sustain the charge.

(a) There must be some definite and specific offense charged, bringing the alien within the excluded class, in order that he may have an opportunity to meet it upon the Government warrant to show cause why he should not be deported;
(b) There must be a hearing on that specific charge:
(c) There must be some evidence adduced which amounts to legal evidence, tending to prove this specific charge;

(d) There must be a finding by the proper authorities, which finding, in order to be legitimate and sufficient, must be based on and fairly deducible from this evidence. A finding which is clearly arbitrary, that is not fairly deducible from such evidence, that is based, rather, upon the opinion of some Inspector or other official, 1
to the exclusion or in disregard of the evidence or one which is arrived at by reason of extraneous circumstances arising subsequent to such hearing, or upon findings based upon some alleged offense other than the one charged in the orginial Warrant, cannot be sustained as a fair and legal hearing; and if such is the case here, it is the duty of the Court to sustain the Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Our contention here is that the petitioners did not have a fair and legal hearing for the following reasons:

1. The Warrant of Arrest, which reads as follows: "Warrant - Arrest of Aliens That the said aliens are unlawfully within the United States in that they have been found assisting, protecting, or promising to protect from arrest, a prostitute or prostitutes." does not definitely charge them with any specific act amount to a violation of the Immigration Act.

2. The Warrant for Deportation, which reads as follows: "Warrant - Deportation of Alien That the said aliens are unlawfully within the United States, in that they have been found assisting a prostitute and protecting or promising to protect from arrest, a prostitute, and may be deported in accordance therewith." does not find them guilty of any specific act amounting to a violation of the Act.
3. There was and if absolutely no evidence in the record what-ever, which can be regarded as legal evidence, tending to prove them guilty of the violation attempted to be charged.

4. The postion now taken by counsel for the Government in his Brief, and which was announced by him for the first time at the hearing on this Habeas Corpus, and which is evidently based upon the letter of opinion of Mr. J.B. Denamore, Solicitor, appended to and 2
as a part of his Brief, not only takes us by surprise, but is clearly a subsequent idea, and is an adroit and desperate effort, after failing on the first, to convict petitioners in some other offense than that in the original Warrant, upon which the hearing was had.
In United States v. Sibray, 178 Fed. pp. 148 and 149,l the Court says:

"I am constrained to hold that the charge is not sufficiently specific. It is not required that the warrant of arrest should have the formality and particularity of an indictment, but it should give to the alien sufficient information of the specific act or acts which bring him within the excluded classes, so that he can offer testimony in refutation of the charge at the hearing directed to be had by the warrant of arrest in pursuance of the act of Congress and the rules of the department. What woman is he charged with importing and for what immoral purpose? Was he convicted of or did he admit the commission of a crime? Was it a felony or other crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude? If either, which was it? By paragraph "b", Rule 35, as has been seen, a fully statement of the facts must be the basis of the warrant. It is contemplated therefore, that facts, and not conclusions, must be set forth in the warrant.
The hearing provided for should be according to established precedent, because that is contemplated by the act and regualtions.
There is no finding that any particular felony, crime, or misdemanor prior to entry was admitted.

I have gone over the testimony taken by the inspector, and do not find any evidence that the relator was convicted of or admits the commission of any offense which can be embraced within the general language of the warrants."

Then can be no doubt, from an inspection of the record, that the said hearing on the Warrant of Arrest was solely and only upon the theory that petitioners had rendered assistance and protection to some prostitute in avoiding arrest. There never was any other idea or charge, either inferentially or otherwise, and no other evidence adduced, than on this one ground. The very letter of information 3
of Thos. M. Fisher, Inspector (see record) recommending this arrest clearly shows this one idea and intention; he says:

"In the view of the facts above mentioned, it would seem to me that noth of these parties are subject to deportation, on the ground that they assisted a prostitute and promised to protect her from arrest."

The charge in the Warrant of Arrest and in the Warrant of Deportation and all the evidence adduced thereon, clearly indicate this one charge of assisting a prostitute from arrest (see also,k letter of Ellis de Bruler, Commissioner of Immigration, to the Commissioner General, dated November 11, 1913, on thee lower third of page 2 thereof), which reads as follows:
He thus refers to the evidence of Ito and Umeda on this point only.

The announcement of counsel for the Government at the hearing of the Habeas Corpus, coming, as it did, frankly and voluntarily, that he had carefully searched through the record in the Immigration proceeding in this case, and failed to find an evidence upon which the Warrant for Deportation could properly be based upon said ground of assisting from arrest, was not a surprise to us, because, we likewise, were unable to find any such evidence. But the subsequent announcement of councel, raising for the first time in this Habeas Corpus proceeding, the question of construction or meaning of the words, "who in any way assists", as used in the Immigration Act and Warrant of Arrest and for Deportation, claiming that said words were not to be construed with the rest of the setence in which they are used, but that Congress really meant and intended to carve out another offense, and provide against the same, than that of assisting from arrest, came as a complete surprise to us, and is clearly an effort 4
now to bolster up a failing cause, and catch the aliens upon some other charge still more indefinite than the first, and upon which they have not had a hearing.
